>>26245510
The concept allows for a reasonably practical car even on a tiny footprint. If done right, you can transport rather large cargo in it. Alternatively, most seat four passengers. Not in great comfort, granted. But they fit inside. Just have to take out the washing machine first.
Sure, you could do the same and more with a Chevy Suburban, but that would be painfully costly and impractical to keep.
Shorter rear-overhang compared to wagon also eases parking in tight, awkward spots, while only few people really need those extra capacities.
In terms of comfort, they may not be absurdly luxurious, but unless you're looking at the most barebone econoboxes it's ok really.

They are a compromise between practical constraints, operational cost and available space

When you have to sell a gorillion cars to recoup the development costs, car manufacturers will trim their model lines down to ensure each individual model sells as many as possible. So yes, it is actually impossible.

>>26245202
That's about the Model 3, which has a 56-76kWh battery and we don't know which Model 3, or how much range that owner likes to preserve after a track session. A lot of tracks don't have charging which can make running the battery down to low states of charge not advisable.
Model 3s generally do about 600-900 Wh/mi on a track depending how how hard they're being driven.
At 900 Wh/mi a Model 3 would use about 45kWh driving 50 miles.

Also consider that most rally special stages are no where near 50 miles long, and even the Nurburgring is only about 13 miles.
If you can't do math, the Lucid Air at 120kWh has more than twice the energy of the lowest end Model 3.

Honestly you guys complain about how all EVs are the same, at the same time you ignore the massive differences that exist between EVs.

>>26245218
>Is being a race car driver a meme?
Yes, the barrier to entry is being rich, or at least middle/upper-middle class with lots of disposable income if including hoopty race cars

>To be a good driver you must not be a pussy which means that you press the throttle all the way and break as late as possible. That's it.
Not really true. That'll just get you into a lot of wrecks. The truth is that a top-level racing driver is like a DJ carefully turning knobs on a mixer to perfectly balance brakes, gas, and steering. The fast and the furious "SLAM the brakes, SLAM the gas, YANK the wheel" is actually a super slow and sloppy technique. The challenge is carefully modulating these precise controls while also being slammed around by 1.5G which is a lot more than people realize.

>If racing a car was as cheap and accessible as playing a football 90% of current proffesional drivers would not exist.
This is probably true, most racing in nicer prepped race cars are actually shit drivers that just paid their way in. The overlap of talented drivers and people with the money for these multi-hundred-thousand-dollar cars is very small. The only thing that's sort of an everyman motorsport is rental karting of which indoor is probably the most respectable for lap times since it's usually geared lower and more intense. The people that run top times in rental karts usually transition very quickly to tracking full-size cars and tend to beat people in more expensive/better prepared cars. This is why I only really respect competition where people are in identically prepared cars or even swapping seats in the same car, but unfortunately these types of races/trials virtually don't exist, it's all based around who wants to spend the most which is gay and I don't respect at all.

You are right that the shittier pay drivers in a lot of motorsports wouldn't exist if it was more accessible, but it's highly unlikely someone who begins karting at 25 with their own money is going to be as experienced as someone who's been sponsored since they were 5. Talent scouts try to find star athletes ASAP, and the rich kids that have their motorsports careers paid for are always going to have the advantage.
>To be a good driver you must not be a pussy which means that you press the throttle all the way and break as late as possible. That's it.
Some of the GOAT F1 drivers (Clark, Prost, Schumacher) were notable not because they were the best at braking late. But because they were the best at driving their car within its mechanical limits over the course of a race to bring it to the finish line. That, combined with tire management and strategy, is what allows cornering and overtaking to happen to begin with.
